I'll weigh in on [tye]'s comments. First, I'll stand by my original comment that it's bad form to post a duplicate as a means of correcting a 'not logged in' issue. If someone posts something anonymously on accident, live and learn; it's not serious enough to trouble the monastery with a consideration vote, and it doesn't warrant pestering the Janitors. I'll also maintain that when we appease the behavior we enable it, or at least, legitimize it. I certanly wouldn't want to encourage what I consider to be a bad practice by obliging the author's request just because he forced a move by double-posting. I still believe that for this reason, and because it's what we normally do with dupes anyway, the second post (the newer duplicate) should be the one to be removed.

As for [tye]'s suggestion that the OP follow up to the anonymous post with a "I wrote this" message, I suppose I'm ok with that. If I considered the anonymously posted message to be worth upvoting, I guess I would probably feel good about upvoting the "I posted this" instead.

While its true that it is possible someone else come along, copy the post, and consider an AM post for deletion, Id like to think that a) people that get to the level where consideration is possible, wouldnt (hopeful, I know), and b) That its pretty unlikely that happen in a such short span of time (ie the time gap between the two posts would be longer, if someone other than the author did it). In fact it was me that suggested [gaal] consider it.

A better solution to this, would possibly be to allow anyone from the same IP, within say 1 minute of posting, to 'claim' an AM post. While it isnt 100% sure (yes, I know about NATing etc), Id like to think we can give people the benefit of the doubt here.

[davido], 2004-08-20
[gaal] considered [id://384692] for deletion, stating he posted it without being logged in. He then double-posted the same text in [id://384696], this time logged in. I voted 'keep' on the original anonymously posted node because I believe: (1) Not being logged in is not a reason to double post. (2) In the event of double-posts, the general rule of thumb is to delete the newer post (the one he posted after logging in). (3) Though I doubt this is has happened in this case, if we reinforce this practice, what's to prevent someone from copycatting [Anonymous Monk] posts in an effort to XP grab? (4) In general, we ought to reinforce the notion that the important thing is that help was given, even if it was mistakenly anonymous. (5) A minimal XP gain that a user might experience by correcting a 'not logged in' issue by double posting is more than offset by the amount of work it creates for others by double-posting and requesting deletion of the original. Let's not encourage people to create extra work just so they'll get a few extra XP.

I stopped short of unconsidering the original node, and considering the duplicate, because I wanted to confirm that my argument is both sound and backed up by precedent. I think the proper course of action should be to unconsider the original, consider the duplicate for deletion (even if the original was anonymous and the duplicate wasn't), and send a friendly reminder to the person mentioning that an easy way to provide a strong visual clue about login status is to use one of the PerlMonks CSS themes. Comments?

    To avoid a conflict of interest--which is what we seem to have here--Judges are expected to recuse themselves when they're a party to an action that comes before them. When a judge takes unilateral action on an issue to which they're a party, the process is corrupted, and people lose confidence in the process.

    [tye], 2004-02-26
    To me, reaping a node is a big deal and not something that should be done unless there is a very good reason with a bright line marking off that reason. Perhaps you (the reader) don't consider it censorship, but I'm sure many do. It certainly has a lot in common with censorship.

    There is absolutely no reason to avoid reaping duplicates (and lots of good reasons to do it). I have no problem even with *nuking* duplicates, provided sufficient time has passed since the duplicate become clearly labeled as a duplicate (probably by being reaped).

    "Is this a duplicate?" is a pretty bright line. The closest case to the line is an exact duplicate of a root node that happens with a wide separation of time and on purpose (to re-ask the question in hopes of getting a better response). And I don't consider that a duplicate. The wide separation in time means that the node should be preserved so that the context of the conversation makes sense.

    Nearly everything else is something I don't want to reap except for rare and extreme cases. Reaping was created in order to deal with abuse (and duplicates). Using it for non-abuse is a bad idea. It doesn't fit. It is the wrong tool.

    "Off-topic" is a very blury line. Reaping should not be done based on blury lines. It should be extremely rare for one person to see value in a node that got reaped.

    The current moderation system doesn't have the right tool for off topic nodes. "Don't" is a pretty good fit in many respects (don't approve such, don't reply to such, don't post such yourself, don't encourage others to...) but it isn't enough for several reasons. One big reason is that people have a need to *do* something. If you think a node is off-topic, it is very unsatisfying to deal with this via *lack* of action. There are other reasons, as well.

    Further, I find many nodes that were considered off-topic to be absolutely on-topic. Not only is this line blury, but it is pretty easy for one person (or many people) to see absolutely no Perl in a node when another sees a whole lot of Perl. This is especially true when people are going out *looking for* off-topic nodes.

    If the hunt for off-topic nodes continues (which it probably will and I'm not saying this is a bad thing -- I find it a mixed blessing), then, IMO, there will be nodes that get voted by consensus as being off-topic that turn out to be *provably* on-topic. Sometimes it is easy to overlook the Perl that really is in the question.

    PerlMonks is not usenet. We don't have a sister site for SQL questions nor for algorithm questions, so it is more than fine to have questions on PerlMonks about using SQL with Perl or discussing generic algorithms in the context of Perl or even discussing the work environment that many Perl programmers deal with, etc. I *want* to see these questions and I want to see them *here*. PerlMonks is a great site for Perlers. And most Perlers benefit from discussions of topics related to Perl that aren't just Perl.

    Even a question that (appears, to you) to be *only* about SQL, is often a good question for PerlMonks. It will often be interesting, informative, or otherwise helpful to no small number of members, will probably end up touching on Perl and explaining the SQL issue in the context of Perl.

    Should we discourage such? Certainly. We don't want to become better at answering SQL questions than some SQL site and steal all of their traffic. We want to keep our focus. And it gets worse if it is an SQL question in the context of Java or PHP and not Perl.

    So we need a way to discourage such. IMHO, it need only be (and should only be) a fairly nuanced shove: a way for the community to vote that a node is off-charter and so can't be approved for any section and you get told why you shouldn't be replying to it if you try to reply to it. It should also make such nodes less visible for those who haven't specifically asked to see such.

    Until we get that, we'll limp along with "don't" and downvote and rant and consider (even though it probably won't get reaped in the end -- so far anyway and I hope that holds up; the fact that a node has been considered should have *some* chilling effect on it) and mark as 'OT' and the occasional reap...

    I don't know what a "useless rant" is. If someone feels strongly enough to rant, then there is a good chance that there is some use to it. We've had *way* off-topic rants turn into fairly big, fairly flamey fests. In such cases, reaping has often made things worse.

    And I've seen a surprising number of what I considered pretty tame jokes get considered as trolls.

    So I don't want to reap rants and I only want to reap *egregious* trolls that are also offensive.

    And, to answer [ybiC]'s original question, I don't "mind" off-topic nodes on PerlMonks much because I hardly ever see any. Usually the ones I see that I consider off-topic are replies, and I have little trouble ignoring them. The degree of off-topicness in root nodes does not appear to be worsening to me. And I don't notice any problematic repeat offenders posting off-topic questions repeatedly.
